qas.question: What  are construction companies asked to plan?

context: In the modern industrialized world, construction usually involves the <b5_0>translation of <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>designs into reality<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>. <b6_0>A formal design team<b6_0/> may be assembled to <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2>plan <b8_0>the physical proceedings, and to integrate those proceedings with the other parts<b8_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. The design usually consists of drawings and specifications, usually prepared by a design team including Architect, civil engineers, mechanical engineers, electrical engineers, structural engineers, fire protection engineers, planning consultants, architectural consultants, and archaeological consultants. The design team is most commonly employed by (i.e. in contract with) <a2_0><a2_1>the <a2_2>property owner<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Under this system, once the design is completed by the design team, a number of construction companies or construction management companies may then be asked to make a bid for the work, either based directly on the design, or on the basis of drawings and a bill of quantities provided by <a3_0>a <a3_1><a3_2>quantity surveyor<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. Following evaluation of bids, the owner typically awards a contract to <a4_0><a4_1><b7_0>the <a4_2>most cost efficient bidder<b7_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>.
